Authors:
CHINGCHAI CHAISIRI, Xiang-Yu Liu, Yang Lin, Yan-Ping Fu,
Fu-Xing Zhu, Chao-Xi Luo
Title:
Phylogenetic and recombination analysis of Diaporthe eres
species complex in China inferred from multiple sequences approach
Keywords:
China; commercial plants; Phomopsis eres; phylogenetic
analysis; population connectivity, species delimitation
Abstract:
Diaporthe eres is considered as one of the most important
causal agents of many plant diseases with broad host range worldwide. In
this study, multiple sequences of ribosomal internal transcribed spacer
region (ITS), translation elongation factor 1-α gene (EF1-α),
beta-tubulin gene (TUB2), calmodulin gene (CAL), histone-3 gene (HIS)
were applied for the multi-locus phylogenetic analysis. For phylogenetic
analysis, maximum likelihood (ML), maximum parsimony (MP), and Bayesian
inferred (BI) approaches were performed to investigate relationships of
D. eres with closely related 51 taxa from 37 species. Results strongly
supported that the D. eres fell into a monophyletic lineage with
characteristics of species complex. In details, phylogenetic
informativeness (PI) analysis showed that clear boundaries could be
proposed by using EF1-α, whereas ITS showed an ineffective
reconstruction, thus unsuitable to speciate boundaries for Diaporthe
species. A combined dataset of EF1-α, CAL, TUB2, and HIS showed strong
resolution for Diaporthe species, providing insights for the D. eres
complex. Accordingly, D. biguttusis, D. camptothecicola, D.
castaneae-mollissimae, D. cotoneastri, D. ellipicola, D. henanensis, D.
longicicola, D. lonicerae, D. mahothocarpus, D. momicola, D. nobilis, D.
rosicola, and Phomopsis fukushii were revealed to be synonyms of D.
eres. In order to demonstrate the genetic diversity of D. eres species
complex in China, 138 D. eres isolates were randomly collected from 16
provinces. These isolates were obtained from difference major plant
cultivars in China, during 2006 to 2020. The phylogenetic analyses and
haplotype networks used to estimate genetic distance revealed two
clusters. Haplotype networks were dispersal by using geographic
distribution analysis, thus not uniquely correlated to specific
populations. Overall, our analyses evaluated the phylogenetic
identification for D. eres species complex and demonstrated the
population diversity of D. eres in China.
